 FOREWORD Centrally planned economies (CPEs) account for a significant share of the world's production and income. In view of their importance in the world economy, and to facilitate international comparative analysis, for many years the World Bank has included statistical data on these countries in those of its publications that aim for universal coverage, such as The World Bank Atlas. Among these data, those relating to gross national product (GNP) and to GNP per capita are the most important, and the Bank also needs them for operational purposes for its member countries, which now include some CPEs. In the CPEs prices are generally set administratively and are often loosely or not at all related to the relative scarcity and costs of production of goods and services. This is particularly true of the exchange rate. The World Bank normally uses exchange rates for converting GNP figures from national currencies into dollars (or into any other numeraire), an indispensable step for international comparisons. The choice of an appropriate conversion factor therefore poses particularly difficult problems for most CPEs. A further difficulty arises because the national accounts of the CPEs are based on the concept of net material product (NMP), which differs from the concept of GNP used in market economies. To derive the GNP numbers of those CPEs that compile only NMP accounts, various adjustments must be made. The data required for making these adjustments are not always fully available. Finally, a separate set of issues arises in relation to year to year comparisons within the same CPE. For these too and the corresponding growth rates, official data are not strictly comparable to growth rates of the market economies.
 In early 1982 a research project sponsored and financed by the World Bank was undertaken to assess alternative methods of computing the per capita dollar GNP levels and growth rates of CPEs. It covered eight countries: Bulgaria, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Poland, Romania and the U.S.S.R. The purpose of this research project was to define the best among known methods that could be applied to CPEs as a group and make use of available data. It was not its aim to establish and define new computation methods whose application would have required many more years of effort, even if data had been available. This research project has produced eleven reports, which are published simultaneously. The main report authored by the principal researcher for the project, Paul Marer, is published as a book, Dollar GNPs of the USSR and Eastern Europe (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1985). The eight country studies and two background papers are published separately in the World Bank Staff Working Paper series. The main report provides highly valuable insights into the problems related to the estimation and comparison of the GNPs and GNP growth rates of the CPEs. It also gives the author's best estimates of the actual values of these indicators for the majority of CPEs covered by the project, that is those for which there was some statistical basis for computing estimates or choosing between those already available. The main report on the Research Project on CPEs concludes that adequate GNP data in national currencies can be derived for most CPEs by adjusting official information about net material product in the light of statistical and other information known to country experts. It further concludes that the best method generally applicable to CPEs for converting such GNP data from local currencies into dollars would use conversion rates based upon purchasing power parity (PPP) information. For comparison with
 corresponding World Bank data on other World Bank members, these conversion rates should be adjusted to correct for the expected differences between the PPP rates and the actual official exchange rates (the "exchange rate deviation index"). The needed adjustments are estimated econometrically from the actual differences observed at each level of per capita GNP among the thirty-one market economies participating in Phase III (1975) of the International Comparison Project (ICP). For Hungary, Romania, and Poland, PPP information is derived from Phase III (1975) of the ICP, while for Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, and the U.S.S.R., it is derived from private bilateral comparisons chain-linked to the ICP data. This method yields a range of per capita GNP estimates: for example, $2,700 to $5,700 with a midpoint of $4,190, for the U.S.S.R. in 1980. No PPP estimate was available, and no GNP per capita figure in US dollars calculated, for Bulgaria and Cuba. The main report also concludes that the official estimates of growth rates of the CPEs "tend to yield varying degrees of upward bias." For all countries except Hungary, the experts lean toward preferring alternative indices, constructed by outside experts with partial information, although these too present problems (especially for countries other than the U.S.S.R.) and the experts therefore fell short of endorsing them. The author of the study on Hungary leans toward preferring the official index at this time. The country studies and background papers that are being issued in the World Bank Staff Working Paper series provide additional details on the CPEs studied and their exchange rates. Some of the country studies include the respective authors' estimates of per capita GNP in U.S. dollars. These estimates, however, are the individual authors' experimental computations, based on methods that may not be consistently applicable to CPEs generally.
 There remain major uncertainties about GNP conversions by means of "adjusted PPPs." In addition to numerous remaining theoretical and practical problems associated with calculating PPPs within the framework of the centrally coordinated ICP, private estimates such as those used in this study for three CPEs still appear to be subject to a wide margin of error. Furthermore, there is no other way to estimate the exchange rate deviation index than to derive it from observation of the countries covered by the ICP (almost all of which are market economies). The applicability of an index derived in this fashion to the CPEs, whose economic structures are very different, remains subject to reservations. The present study used ICP Phase III data relating to the year 1975, extrapolated to 1980. Phase IV ICP data already published shows estimates directly relating to 1980 for European countries, including Hungary and Poland; Romania, a participant in early phases of the ICP, has not provided the data needed for participation in Phase IV. It is noteworthy that Phase IV estimates of Hungary's and Poland's per capita GNP in 1980 are lower than the 1975 results extrapolated to 1980, used by the Research Report on CPEs. These differences are partly due to the greater attention paid in Phase IV to quality differences and to other methodological advances. During the course of 1983 the Bank, with the help of a distinguished panel of experts, 1/ undertook a review of the methodological problems and issues related to the estimation of internationally comparable per capita GNP figures for all countries. The preliminary results of the research project on CPEs constituted an important input into that review, whose findings and 1/ Abram Bergson, Harvard University, Chairman; Andre Vanoli, Institut National de la Statistique et des Etudes Economiques; and Parmeet Singh, Commonwealth Secretariat.
 recommendations were approved by the panel of experts. In light of the review, the Bank has decided that for the time being (that is, at least until data availability and other problems related to PPP information are resolved), official GNP information converted at official exchange rates should generally continue to provide the basis of the per capita GNP estimates published in The World Bank Atlas. Exceptions to this rule are to be made only when official GNP data, in national currency, is exceptionally bad or compiled in ways which diverge in an exceptionally large measure from the usual methods and standards, or when the official exchange rate is exceptionally far removed from the rate effectively governing foreign payments transactions. When there is a reason to believe that such exceptional circumstances prevail, and adequate information exists, appropriate adjustments are to be made. When adequate information does not exist and cannot be obtained, no estimates are to be published. At the time of writing this foreword, it seems likely that lack of information will for some time prevent the Bank from making estimates of the per capita GNP of most CPEs. Thus The World Bank Atlas published in early 1985 contains an estimate of the values of GNP and GNP per capita for only one European CPE, Hungary. Following the review endorsed by the panel of experts, the World Bank has adopted calculation methods and obtained results which, for a few countries, are different from those of the research project of CPEs. The Bank's general methodology must be applicable to all its member countries, including most market economies and only a few CPEs; the Bank could demand that its member countries provide additional information when needed; and it could, and did, decide not to estimate the per capita GNP of countries for which a minimal, but still fairly extensive set of information could not be obtained. As noted earlier, however, the research project on CPEs has aimed
 at defining a method consistently applicable to all CPEs and one that could make use of available information. These differences in aims and constraints readily explain the differences in results. The research project on CPEs, whose major findings are published in the main report, has greatly enhanced the understanding of the CPEs' unique macroeconomic accounting frameworks and pricing systems. It has provided insight into many substantive issues, in particular the relationship of domestic and international prices. The individual country reports, published separately, shed much light on many important country-specific issues. The Bank will continue to build upon the valuable findings of the research project on CPEs in its future efforts to understand these important components of the global economy.  ABSTRACT This paper presents the results of a survey and critical analysis of Cuban national accounts data. The paper first reviews available Cuban data on the Material Product System (MPS), pointing out their strengths and limitations. Then it carries out a similar analysis with respect to gross domestic product (GDP) estimates based on the System of National Accounts (SNA) and discusses inflation in Cuba and the difficulties in establishing the proper peso/dollar exchange rate. The paper concludes with some judgments regarding the most promising method for estimating Cuban GDP per capita in dollars.
 SUMMARY This paper presents the results of a survey and critical review of Cuban national accounts data we undertook as part of the World Bank Project on CPE National Income Statistics. Our objective was to gather and review all available official Cuban national product statistics and independent estimates both on the Material Product System (MPS) and the System of National Accounts (SNA) with respect to reliability, consistency and reasonableness. In particular, we were interested in determining if there were reliable estimates of Cuban GDP/capita in dollars for certain benchmark years (1965, 1970, 1975, 1980), or of growth rates, which could be used to gauge the performance of the Cuban economy. Finally, we were also interested in evaluating methodologies which could be used to make meaningful estimates of Cuban GDP/capita in dollars. We found that Cuban data on the MPS are scanty, highly aggregated, frequently revised, and affected by numerous methodological changes which are not usually described. Data on the net material product (NMP) are only available for 1962-66 and on gross material product (GMP) for 1962-75 and 1977-78, mostly at current prices. No time series data have ever been published on the value of nonmaterial services (NMS). Data on the global social product (GSP) are available for the entire period 1962-81 but are of limited use because of methodological changes that result in four subseries
 which cannot be connected. Quantity indexes of industrial production are not available either. The review of indicators of Cuban aggregate economic performance under the SNA included an estimate of Cuban GDP for 1974 prepared by Cuban statisticians which resulted from a full-fledged MPS-SNA conversion exercise, some data purportedly on growth rates of Cuban GNP reported in Soviet sources, estimates of Cuban GDP, of GDP/capita in dollars, or of their growth rates made by independent organizations such as the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency, the U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and the World Bank, and our own estimates of Cuban GDP/capita in dollars made using the physical indicators approach. We also considered the possibility of scaling up to GDP by adding the value of NMS and depreciation to NMP. After a careful review of all of the available information, we found that none of the available estimates of Cuban GDP/capita, including our own estimates based on physical indicators, appear to be reliable. Similarly, estimates of growth rates of GDP/capita appear to suffer from lack of relilability. Further, it is not feasible to use the scaling up method because of the lack of availability of data on NMP and on the value of NMS. However, Cuban officials have indicated their intention to extend the MPS-SNA conversion exercise to other years. The resulting estimates of GDP/capita could be the basis for further work to gauge the performance of the Cuban economy. Estimates of GDP/capita resulting from this MPS-SNA conversion exercise are likely to be in pesos at current prices. In order to make meaningful international comparisons, they would need to be converted to constant prices and to dollars. As we note in the paper, an important, and
 growing, part of the Cuban economy is affected by inflation. Thus, the expansion of the government-controlled parallel market, the "free peasant" markets and the dramatic increase in official consumer prices at the end of 1981 are evidence of the increasing relevance of inflation in the Cuban economy. Despite this growing importance, there are no official data on the price level in Cuba. Our analysis of the peso-dollar exchange rate has led us to the conclusion, also reached by many others, that the official exchange rate far overstates the purchasing power of the peso. However, there is no reliable information on the degree of overvaluation which would permit the estimation of alternative exchange rates.

 INTRODUCTION At the start of the 1960s, the Cuban government began to pursue a socialist development path and made significant changes in economic organization, including the adoption of central planning. As a result of these changes the statistical data collection and processing system was severely disrupted and the material balances system, more compatible with central planning, adopted as the basic national accounting system. Thus, for most economic series, a gap exists for 1959-61 and, beginning with 1962, published data follow the Material Product System (MPS), which differs substantially from the System of National Accounts (SNA) methodology used by pre-revolutionary Cuba and by nearly all non-socialist nations. Although the availability of Cuban economic data has improved over the years, the Cuban government continues to provide only minimal data on the national product and those which are available are subject to frequent revisions and changes in methodology. At different points since 1964 the Cuban government has published time series data on the global social product (GSP), the gross material product (GMP) or the net material product (NMP), but only GSP is available for the entire period 1962-81, albeit not calculated with a consistent methodology. In 1982, Cuba for the first time released some national product data following the SNA. All of the national product data available from Cuban official sources are given in domestic currency (Cuban pesos). Whereas the Cuban peso has not been freely exchanged in international markets since 1962, it is not clear what exchange rate should be used to convert Cuban data in pesos to another currency basis. Because of the inadequacies in the official national product data, several organizations outside of Cuba have made estimates of Cuba gross
 - 2 - domestic product (GDP) or of gross domestic product per capita (GDP/capita) in dollars. These efforts, which have relied on different methodologies, have yielded estimates of Cuban national product significantly different from one another and from trends implied by the available official indicators. This paper presents the results of a survey and critical review of Cuban national product data and estimates we undertook as part of the World dank Project on CPE National Income Statistics. Our objective was to gather and review all available official Cuban national product statistics and independent estimates with respect to reliability, consistency and reasonableness. In particular, we were interested in determining if there were reliable estimates of Cuban GDP/capita in dollars for certain benchmark years (1965, 1970, 1975 and 1980), or of growth rates, which could be used to gauge the performance of the Cuban economy. Finally, we were also interested in evaluating methodologies which could be used to make meaningful estimates of Cuban GDP/capita in dollars. In the first Section of this study we review available Cuban national product data based on the MPS, pointing out their strengths and limitations. In the second Section we carry out a similar analysis with respect to estimates of Cuban national product data based on the SNA, especially the estimate for 1974 made by Cuban statisticians. To the extent that is was possible, we assess the methodologies used to make each of the estimates. We also explore the possibility of making estimates of Cuban GDP/capita using two other approaches: "scaling up" from NMP (or GMP) and physical indicators. In Section 3 we discuss inflation in Cuba and in Section 4 we comment briefly on the difficulties in establishing the proper peso/dollar exchange rate. The paper concludes with our evaluation of the body of data and estimates on Cuban

Since 1977 (and retrospec- tively for 1975-76) the method used is identified as "value at enterprise exit" (a salida de empresa) except for agricultural output, which continues to be calculated under the complete circulation method. Neither of the two terms has been clearly defined in Cuban publications. As we understand it, output valued at enterprise exit is calculated using the producer's price, i.e., the value of the output of material goods (including materials services) at the point they leave the producing enterprise (including circulation tax). On the other hand, complete circulation value is calculated using the purchaser's price, i.e., the producer's price plus the value of "circulation," i.e., transportation, storage and trade. Since the value of these material services are already counted under the output of the transportation and trade sectors, the complete circulation technique results in double counting. The method of output valuation "at enterprise exit," currently in use, avoids this duplication. Another interpretation of the methodological distinction, based on United Nations definitions, is that value at "enterprise exit" is equivalent to the "enterprise method" used in CPEs to value industrial output (which excludes intermediate consumption) while "complete circulation" is equivalent to the "gross turnover method" used to value agricultural output (which includes intermediate consumption). /8 The only Cuban reference to the /8 United Nations, Basic Principles of the System of Balances of the National Economy, Series F, No. 17 (New York: United Nations, 1971), pp. IT,-4 8.--

Alternative Measures of Cuban National Product under the SNA In addition to the official Cuban national product data on the MPS discussed above, there are other indicators of Cuban aggregate economic performance under the SNA which deserve careful attention. Of primary importance are an estimate of Cuban GDP for 1974 prepared by Cuban statisticians for an international seminar on MPS/SNA conversion and some data purportedly on growth rates of Cuban GNP reported in Soviet sources. Soviet Data on Cuban GNP Since 1976, the International Bank for Economic Cooperation (IBEC) has been publishing an Economic Bulletin which occasionally reports growth rates of national income and industrial production of its members, including Cuba. Although data for Cuba are sometimes not reported, when they are they refer to growth in "gross national product (GNP)," rather than in national income and in industrial production. The possibility that Cuba might have been reporting estimates of growth in GNP to IBEC for over ten years and not publishing these data domestically or, alternatively, that IBEC has made independent estimates of growth in Cuban GNP is intriguing. The IBEC has not explained why it has chosen to report Cuban economic performance in terms of growth rates of GNP rather than of national income, as it is done for the other member countries, or how it has converted Cuban GSP data to obtain GNP. Further, IBEC does not indicate whether the reported data are based on data at current or constant prices. While we can not definitively rule out that the data reported by IBEC might indeed be the result of an actual MPS/SNA conversion, we are highly skeptical. Instead, we suspect that in some cases the IBEC might be reporting changes in GSP rather than in GNP (as it appears to be the case for 1978) and in others the reported data are erroneous.

Demand swelled due to the raise in population income (or disposable income) generated by full employment, guaranteed annual wages, increased minimum wages and pensions, and expansion of free social services. The supply of consumer goods was negatively affected by stagnation in domestic output, reduction of imports and exportation of goods previously destined for internal consumption. For political and social reasons, the Cuban government decided in 1962 to freeze prices of consumer goods and to introduce rationing rather than allow prices to rise. Most families, however, received incomes which far exceeded the value of their personal consumption--that is, the cost of the monthly ration basket of goods and of the few nonrationed goods and non-free social services available.
 - 53 - The difference between the population income and the value of its personal consumption is the monetary surplus--that is, excess money in circulation with which goods or services cannot be acquired. According to the estimates of one of the authors (Table 21), the monetary surplus steadily increased in the 1960s so that in 1970 it had reached a peak of 86 percent over the population income. In other words, in 1970 the income of the population exceeded by almost twofold the value of goods and services available for purchase. This situation, officially described as one of "tremendous inflation," did not result in price increases of rationed goods but reduced work incentives, encouraged labor absenteeism (officially estimated at 20 percent of the labor force in 1970) and sent prices in the black market skyrocketing. In order to reduce the money in circulation, consumer demand was curtailed by establishing the parallel market, which increased prices of goods, postponing or abandoning promises of eliminating rents and increasing minimum wages, charging a fee for services previously provided free, etc., and the supply of goods was increased by expanding production or imports of certain consumer durables. As a result of these measures, the monetarysurplus was reduced in 1971-75, hence inducing "a deflationary process." /27 But world inflation, accelerated after 1973 by the energy crisis, together with the decline in world sugar prices which forced the curtailment of imports, resulted in a new expansion of the monetary surplus in 1976-78. Personal consumption (C p) includes all expenditures by household units on goods and material services, such as purchases of goods sold.in state retail stores and free peasant markets, fees paid for public utilities and transportation, cost of home repair, consumption of state-subsidized meals, housing depreciation, private farmers' self consumption, etc. Also included as personal consumption is material consumption by units of the nonmaterial sphere serving individuals. Collective or social consumption (Cc) refers to consumption done by institutions which satisfy collective needs. The sum of personal and social consumption results in "total [final] consumption." Gross fixed capital formation or gross investment (I) refers to all expenditures by the state in fixed assets. Subtraction of consumption of fixed capital or depreciation (D) from I yields net fixed capital formation or net investment. Both gross and net investment exclude replacement of fixed assets due to losses. Variations in stocks (S) refer to increases or decreases in inventories of raw materials, fuels, spare parts, tools, etc., and may include changes in material circulating assets. The sum of gross investment and variations in capital stocks results in "capital accumulation." Exports (X), fob basis, and imports (M), cif basis, include all sales and purchases abroad of goods and services, as well as gifts of material goods granted or received from abroad. Transactions of nonproductive services are excluded.
 - 78 - The "disposable product" is defined as the sum of total consumption and capital accumulation. The sum of the disposable product and net exports (X - M) yields the GMP. "Global demand" is obtained by adding exports to the disposable product, while the "global supply" is defined as the sum of GMP and imports. Intermediate consumption or intermediate material inputs (Ci) embraces all expenditures in raw materials, fuels, electricity, losses, productive services, transportation and communications involved in material production and distribution. The sum of GMP and intermediate consumption is the GSP. From the product side, the GSP consists of the value of goods and material services generated by the productive sphere. It includes estimates of the value of private farmers' self-consumption and sales to free peasant markets, the value of transportation created by private truckers and taxi drivers, the material value created by the self-employed and, at least since 1973, the value of the product of the private agricultural sector linked to the state sector (which is practically all). Official Cuban GSP statistics exclude the value of the following nonmaterial services: personal and communal services and housing; education, culture and art; public health and social security, recreation, sports and tourism; science and technology; finance, credit and insurance; and defense and state administration. Thus, the Cuban national product accounting system follows closely the MPS and is consistent with those used by the USSR and other CPEs and described in various United Nations publications. In fact, several reports of the National Bank refer to the MPS methodology described by the United Nations in Basic Principles of the System of National Balances of the National Economy.

After careful examination, the ECE concluded that the parameter characteristics between the two sets of countries were so significant that the estimating equations obtained from the larger sample were characteristic of neither of the two groups. /56 Thus, the ECE preferred to continue to estimate GDP/capita in dollars for the Eastern European countries and the Soviet Union using the "homogeneous" original set of 22 high-income industrial countries. The 28 reference countries we have selected for estimating Cuban GDP/capita are believed to be representative of the structure and level of development of the Cuban economy during the 1960s and 1970s (see Table D-1). Our intention was to consider in our work all 30 physical indicators used by the ECE in the revised exercise, but this turned out to be impossible because of data limitations. After considerable research, we were able to assemble relatively complete data for 24 physical indicators series for at least one of the four years under consideration: 1965, 1970, 1975 and 1977 (see Table D-3). The lack of data is particularly noticeable in the area of consumption of industrial products, where only one reasonably complete series (steel consumption) could be found compared to six in the revised ECE work. The Beckerman-Bacon multivariate approach is conceptually similar to the univariate methods of the ECE, and has been used to estimate GDP/capita in dollars for some CPEs. Through a stepwise regression using the backward-elimination procedure we have attempted to find the strongest subset of indicators which could be used to explain the variability in GDP/capita for the reference countries. The procedure starts with all independent variables (the set of 24 indicators) as explanatory variables and removes one at a time according to its contribution to the overall explanatory power of the equation. doc.repnme: A study of Cuba's material product system, its conversion to the system of national accounts, and estimation of gross domestic product per capita and growth rates
doc.abstracts: This paper presents the results of a survey and critical analysis of Cuban national accounts data. The paper first reviews available Cuban data on the Material Product System (MPS), pointing out their strengths and limitations. Then it carries out a similar analysis with respect to gross domestic product (GDP) estimates based on the System of National Accounts (SNA) and discusses inflation in Cuba and the difficulties in establishing the proper peso/dollar exchange rate. The paper concludes with some judgments regarding the most promising method for establishing Cuban GDP per capita in dollars.
